Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: strong understanding of multi variable calc. much better course than 115 but also a decent amount harder

Introduction to basic theory and the fundamentals of practical multivariable calculus. This class is heavily taught with a focus for doing; it emphasizes the procedures of computation over any more general understanding of the underlying theory. Connections are developed between dimensions within calculus.
I learned much about calculus in three dimensions
vector calc, surface integrals, up to triple integrals, stokes divergence greens theorems
I learned a lot about multi variable calculus, from partial derivatives to flux integrals. These math skills will hopefully help me in courses related to my major such as physics.
Gained important information regarding multivariable and vector calculus.
I have learned a great deal about three dimensional spaces and performing various calculations of volume, surface area, flux, etc. over those regions.
I learned a deeper understanding of multivaribale calculus.

Besides learning how to compute double and triple integrals of multiple varieties and scalar and vector line integrals, I also became much better at visualizing 3D space and drawing and recognizing surfaces. A great deal of information was covered in the course and the material moves rather fast and builds up on itself so it is very important to stay on top of things. Greens Theorem, Stokes Theorem, and Divergence Theorem were the bridges to go between different dimensions of integrals.
I learned multivariable calculus, and I also learned how to study better going forward.
I learned pretty much exactly what was in the textbook we used for multivariable calculus. No surprises.

math 
multivariable
I learned about the basics of vector operations. I also learned many approaches to solving scalar and vector line integrals, scalar surface integrals, and flux integrals.
Learned a lot in this class. I felt like I mastered a lot of the mathematical tools like Vector Integrals, Stokes Theorem, Divergence Theorem, Multiple Integrals and many other things.

i developed knowledge of many types of integrals including vector integrals, scalar integrals, triple integrals, and others. in addition to this i learned about vectors (although i already knew vectors from IB math) and chain rule for differentiation.

multivariable calculus
problem solving
quantitative reasoning

A WHOLE LOT. I learned pretty much everything about multivariable calculus this semester because i had no experience coming in. The class was very thorough and all-encompassing. There is a lot of material that is gone through fairly quickly. Imagine, everything you learned in Differential and Integral Calculus but now applied to larger dimensions.
Improves 3 dimensional mathematics skills.

strengths: lectures, depending on which teacher you have. Sudesh is a really really good teacher.

weaknesses: sometimes the homeworks have integrals where it takes 1 minute to figure out the procedure and 15 minutes to solve the integral. in other words, sometimes you spend way more time doing annoying algebra and trig substitution than you spend practicing the methods from class

In my opinion, a focus more towards problem solving and towards understanding conceptually and mathematically what exactly each theorem means would be better. More harder problems that require creative, non-formulaic thinking, that aren't readily apparent at first, and that can be solved through a application of the taught principles in a novel or creative way would be better.
The faculty was outstanding and they made this class, while hard, very enjoyable and interesting
AMAZING CLASS WITH SUDESH! TAKING THE CLASS WITH HIM DETERMINES WHETHER OR NOT YOU DO WELL/LEARN! HES THE BEST TEACHER

Strengths: Interesting content.

Weaknesses/To be Improved: The distribution of content between the exams was somewhat unbalanced. There was too little content for the first midterm, too much content for the second midterm, and way too much content after midterm 2 that we were supposed to learn before the final. A healthier balance of content distribution should be pursued.
Well structured. Material for exam prep (especially review questions) was well-prepared. Review sessions and lectures were both productive.

Strengths - I really enjoy math and went to office hours on occasion to improve

Weakness - At times I fell behind and had to catch up on content

Strengths: Sudesh
Weaknesses: Grading is harsh. You can know all the material, but because there are so many steps it's easy to do all the right things and still get only half of the points. It's frustrating and feels unfair.

Another weakness: instructors. Sudesh is a god, but the others are severely lacking. Daping is good as well, though I only know through review sessions so my opinion may differ from others.
I think the final should not be worth as much as it is put. It makes the midterms less of a big deal when so many students work so hard for those.

The biggest strength of the course is instructor Sudesh Kalyanswamy. The biggest weakness is that not every student in Math 120 can experience his expertise. A great deal of information is covered in the course and the material moves rather fast and builds up on itself so it is very important to stay on top of things. Sudesh made worksheets to accompany every lecture and using these as tools to ensure my understanding was paramount to my success. Although it is very easy to fall behind, if you are willing to put in the effort you will be able to do relatively well using the many resources provided. Lectures were incredibly helpful but I would like to emphasize the fact that this is very much dependent on the instructor. Without a good instructor, it would be extremely difficult to do well in this course.

Strengths: I had Sudesh, and he explained the concepts really well. Also, the weekly homework assignments are manageable.

Weaknesses: Some students took multivariable calculus in high school, so they kill the curve. The course covers a lot of material very quickly, and the three exams are worth 90% of the course grade. Homework is assigned during the midterm weeks.

This course is taught in a logical way such that the concepts you learn can be reapplied in various scenarios, which helped me understand the concepts better. This class can go pretty fast such that it may move onto the next topic before you really understand or practice the previous concept. This fast pace is just the nature of the course, and I think Sudesh did a good job in reinforcing previous concepts rather than just assuming everyone fully remembered previous concepts.

Overall I think the strengths and weaknesses lie with the professors. I shopped several sections and it was clear that some professors were simply more prepared with handouts and extra problem sheets (just overall more resources to help students succeed) than others.

The course provides a comprehensive overview of multi-variable calculus. However, it feels a bit disjointed at times, and the material does not come together until the end of the course. This might just be the nature of multi-variable calculus, but it would be nice if more cohesion could be attained sooner in the semester.

MATH 120 in general is very well-structured, designed in a way that helps the student and insightful. For midterms and Finals, we had multiple review sessions. Office hours also help a lot and Professor Sudesh was very committed to make himself available most of the time especially during Finals period.

strengths: very solid knowledge of integrals, IF you put in the work
weakness: the class moves so fast!!

strengths:
- intellectually challenging
- stretches your problem solving abilities
- develops analytical thinking

The biggest strength of this course by far was the professor. Professor Kalyanswamy is easily the best professor I have had at Yale. He is extremely approachable, and very intelligent. I have never had a question he is unwilling or unable to answer. His office hours are actually the greatest things in existence. I would always go to them with a billion questions and come out feeling confident in the material. His lectures were stunningly clear and well organized. He also made difficult and somewhat tedious material seems very engaging. 
Other strengths of the course include the limitless outside resources available for Math 120 students, and the community of mutual struggling the class can bring.

There were also many weaknesses for this class. The biggest weakness was definitely the nit-pickiness of the exams. Many problems seemed garnered towards lowering students' grades than actually testing material. Also, the sheer number of kids who have taken multi in the class makes the curve brutal. Lastly, the PSETS (although usually not hard) can become very tedious and unnecessarily long.

You're probably not taking 120 for fun. I recommend taking it with Sudesh, he is by far the best lecturer in math that I've seen. If you can't get his section the class will be a bit harder but still take it if you have to - it's not bad.
Not the best math class to take for fun. Really only necessary as a refresher of calculus or as a necessary prerequisite.
100% Sudesh was one of the best teachers I have ever encountered.

Definitely take this with Sudesh! Its an absolute must. He spends so much time to making sure his students are learning. Tons of office hours, review sessions, and very well-taught class. Also, Math 120 is NOT a hard class when you take it with Sudesh. It is the same (if not easier) compared to most of the other classes here. Sudesh is a MUST though. Friends in a different section (with diff professors) have had a worse time. Sudesh is definitely the way to go (also this is a FUN class)
Yes if they need it for their major. I recommend you take it with Sudesh with possible!
Yes, definitely a useful, well-organized course.
For those who are interested in furthering their quantitative skills this class is kind of necessary whether you want to do Econ, Math, etc. However, nonetheless it does teach some important skills.
If you get Sudesh, YES. Otherwise, you might be okay but you'll struggle a little more. Odds are your taking it as a requirement so you probably don't have a choice.
Yes, it teaches good skills for later in life.

I was trying to decide between Math 120 and ENAS 151 and the choice entirely came down to professor. Although Math 120 does cover more material, I am extraordinarily happy I chose to take it because a good professor is more important than the difficulty of the course. Sudesh Kalyanswamy is the best professor I have ever had and as a result of the endless resources he provided to us, I was able to do well. Although it is very easy to fall behind, if you are willing to put in the effort you will be able to do relatively well using the many resources provided. Really pay attention to lecturer though when making your decision because this variable profoundly affects your chances of success.

I shopped both MATH 120 and ENAS 151, and since they both teach the same material but ENAS 151 focuses on applications, I chose MATH 120 for a more abstract understanding (and because I knew Sudesh is a great professor).

Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone who would fine this math content applicable, especially if you get Sudesh. But beyond the content of the course I dont think you learn much mathematical reasoning or practice applications beyond the basics. Since the course moves so fast the course is mostly computational.
Yes

Yes. I think that this course is crucial for anyone in the physical sciences or economics (and math of course). It provides a solid foundation that will give you many tools to approach mathematical problems that will certainly be useful in later courses.
If you are an Engineering, life science or any other STEM major, you need to take this class.
absolutely! i loved math 120, i genuinely enjoyed the classroom time and i felt it prepared me really well as a prereq for the statistics major.
Only to STEM majors. Great course but a humanities major may not appreciate it.

I would HIGHLY recommend this course to another student ONLY if they get Professor Kalyanswamy. It is legit worth waiting a semester to get him. All the students in his class had a much firmer grasp over the material than students in other classes. Also, unlike many Yale professors, he teaches the material from scratch and does not assume we know things we don't. If you put in the work, got to office hours and ask him questions (he's super approachable), I don't see a way to not do well in this course.
Yes, the class was easier and better taught than Math 115.
